informal_statement:
If $|x - 2| = p$, where $x < 2$, then $x - p =$

$ \textbf{(A)} \ -2 \qquad \textbf{(B)} \ 2 \qquad \textbf{(C)} \ 2-2p \qquad \textbf{(D)} \ 2p-2 \qquad \textbf{(E)} \ |2p-2|  $ Show that it is \text{(C)2-2p}.
informal_proof:
When $x < 2,$ $x-2$ is negative so $|x - 2| = 2-x = p$ and $x = 2-p$.

Thus $x-p = (2-p)-p = 2-2p$.
$\text{(C)2-2p}$
formal_statement:
theorem amc12_2000_p5:
  fixes x p ::real
  assumes "x<2"
    and "\<bar>x -2\<bar> = p"
  shows "x - p = 2 - 2 * p"
formal_code:

theorem amc12_2000_p5:
  fixes x p ::real
  assumes "x<2"
    and "\<bar>x -2\<bar> = p"
  shows "x - p = 2 - 2 * p"
  using assms by auto
